quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Reframes onboarding as the one universal surface area, making it a uniquely high-leverage place to invest for growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's also the first opportunity that you have as a company to deliver on the promise that you made out in the marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Highlights onboarding as the earliest moment to validate marketing claims with real product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Provides a simple mental model linking brand positioning directly to product execution.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other, or you're going to have mismatched expectations and some really disappointed customers.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Warns that misalignment between brand promise and onboarding/product reality creates expectation gaps that drive dissatisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So this is the first chance that a customer has to be really excited or really disappointed in what they thought they were getting. So don't mess that up.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Emphasizes the high-stakes nature of onboarding as the first emotional inflection point in the customer journey.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Linear
quotes.text: Coda's an all-in one doc that combines the best of documents, spreadsheets, and apps in one place.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical framing for consolidating fragmented tools into a single workspace to reduce context switching.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Linear
quotes.text: It's my home base for organizing my newsletter writing, it's where I plan my content calendar, capture my research, and write the first drafts of each and every post.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of using one system as an end-to-end workflow hub from planning through execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Linear
quotes.text: Some of the best teams out there like Pinterest, Spotify, Square and Uber, use Coda to run effectively and have published their templates for anyone to use.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a reusable best-practice approach: adopt proven templates from high-performing teams rather than reinventing processes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Linear
quotes.text: Let's be honest, the issue tracker that you're using today isn't very helpful.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian prompt to question default tooling and whether it’s creating drag instead of enabling progress.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Linear
quotes.text: What users love about Linear are the powerful keyboard shortcuts, efficient GitHub integrations, cycles that actually create progress, and built in project updates that keep everyone in sync.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A checklist of workflow features that practitioners can use to evaluate or improve their team’s execution system.

quotes.topic_title: Adam’s career overview and current work
quotes.text: Now, I do three things primarily, I'm an EIR at Reforge and a program partner, which means I create courses. I run an advisory practice on growth and product strategy, which keeps me pretty busy, and then I recently started a newsletter which was pretty much inspired by your work in this area over the last several years. Those are the three pillars of my life these days, my professional life at least.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A simple “three pillars” model for structuring a portfolio career across teaching/creation, advising, and writing.

quotes.topic_title: Adam’s career overview and current work
quotes.text: Well, I'm pretty busy, but it is a bit of a revolving door, so there's always some pipeline. So even if I can't work with folks right now, sometimes it makes sense for me to work with them a few months down the road. So always open to new interest and learning about new companies.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Practical guidance for engaging an advisor: treat availability as a pipeline and plan for a delayed start rather than a hard “no.”

quotes.topic_title: Early Lyft memories and launch story
quotes.text: I have a ton of memories from the almost three years that I was there, but I think the biggest one, and probably the most tactile or memorable thing was when we launched Lyft, when we were bringing it out of private beta, we had this press event at the office, which is in Soma, and it had these doors, these big huge garage style doors.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A concrete example of marking the transition from private beta to launch with a high-signal, memorable event.

quotes.topic_title: Early Lyft memories and launch story
quotes.text: And so we opened them up and we actually drove a car into the office with a pink mustache on the front of it, and then a bunch of drivers piled out of it and met the press members and were high fiving people and stuff like that.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Illustrates how a bold, theatrical product moment can create press-friendly storytelling and community energy.

quotes.topic_title: Early Lyft memories and launch story
quotes.text: And then we also served a giant pink mustache cake at this event.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A specific example of reinforcing brand identity through a memorable, shareable detail at launch.

quotes.topic_title: Super Pumped reflections and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
quotes.text: It was like renavigating, relitigating a history that I had lived through already.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Highlights the emotional and cognitive cost of revisiting past competitive battles—useful for leaders planning retrospectives or postmortems.

quotes.topic_title: Super Pumped reflections and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
quotes.text: Another part of me was happy to see that all of the things were out in the open finally, things that were hard to talk about about competitive practices and stuff like that and just shady things.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Suggests transparency about uncomfortable competitive realities can be validating and clarifying for teams navigating similar dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Super Pumped reflections and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
quotes.text: And we had this conversation over Zoom when he was on break in between scenes of filming the show.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A concrete example of meeting candidates/partners where they are—being flexible with timing and context to make high-value conversations happen.

quotes.topic_title: Super Pumped reflections and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
quotes.text: So he did this interview with me and he was in his trailer on set, fully decked out as TK in his look with his hair slicked back.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A vivid, specific anecdote that underscores how context can shape perception—and why separating role from person matters in interviews and collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Super Pumped reflections and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
quotes.text: Obviously they're both super successful, but JGL is a really down to earth, nice, very family-oriented calm guy.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Counterbalances the “successful leaders must be aggressive” trope by pointing out a contrasting, calmer success archetype.

quotes.topic_title: Why Adam wrote the growth competency model
quotes.text: I don't think I've ever come across this type of canonical reference before around how to hire and plan for growth. So that's number one. I didn't think it existed. It needed to exist.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Highlights the need for a shared, durable framework (not ad hoc heuristics) for hiring and planning growth.

quotes.topic_title: Why Adam wrote the growth competency model
quotes.text: I get asked all the time about how do you hire growth people? And it's usually something like, "Hey, how do we find you but 10 years earlier in your career?" And it feels like that question is missing the first principles approach to hiring a growth person.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Calls out a common hiring anti-pattern—searching for replicas instead of defining first-principles competencies.

quotes.topic_title: Why Adam wrote the growth competency model
quotes.text: And if you're doing that, you're just pattern matching to me. And I may not be the best person, right, or somebody who looks like me may not be the best person.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A memorable warning that “pattern matching” candidates can systematically miss the best fit for the actual growth problem.

quotes.topic_title: Why Adam wrote the growth competency model
quotes.text: And the founders of that company we're looking for what I would call a silver bullet strategy to their growth challenges.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A cautionary example of founders mis-scoping growth leadership as a one-off fix rather than a system.

quotes.topic_title: Why Adam wrote the growth competency model
quotes.text: Executing a growth strategy takes time and patience, and they didn't really have it.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to align expectations on timeline and iteration cadence before hiring a growth leader.

quotes.topic_title: Model overview: four competency buckets
quotes.text: So the goal of the competency model is not to find a unicorn human being that is an 11 out of 10 on every one of these things, because frankly, that person doesn't exist.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Reframes hiring away from “unicorns” toward a realistic, team-based approach to covering growth skill gaps.

quotes.topic_title: Model overview: four competency buckets
quotes.text: The goal is to create a well-rounded team so that you're hiring and balancing skills across your team and that you don't have any gaps in your portfolio.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for building a balanced growth org by explicitly managing skill coverage across the team.

quotes.topic_title: Model overview: four competency buckets
quotes.text: And so when you think about it, there are four main components to the growth competency model. And the four big components or buckets are growth execution, customer knowledge, growth strategy, and then the last one is communication and influence.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Provides the core four-bucket framework practitioners can use for hiring, leveling, and performance evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Model overview: four competency buckets
quotes.text: You can almost use it as a reverse interviewing characteristic and say, "What are the competencies you, founder, CEO, care about? What's really important to you for the first person in this role? Or the expectations that you have of what I will bring to the table."
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A practical method to surface alignment (or misalignment) early by interviewing stakeholders on competency expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Model overview: four competency buckets
quotes.text: So rather than saying, "Adam, you really need to be more strategic." Everybody's heard that at some point and it's like, "Well, what do you mean?" You can say, "Hey, we need to work on the area of growth strategy and that means I need to see better modeling of loops out of you, better understanding communication of what those loops are."
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Shows how to turn vague performance feedback into specific, coachable behaviors using the competency model.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: customer knowledge and user psychology
quotes.text: most people come to your product with an emotional frame and a lot of people want to appeal to their logical brain right away. And the reality is, don't do that.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to lead with users’ emotional state rather than logical arguments when designing growth/product experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: customer knowledge and user psychology
quotes.text: you have to understand the mindset that people are in. How low are their lows? How high are their highs? Why are they seeking out your product?
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A practical set of diagnostic questions for uncovering user motivation and emotional context behind product adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: customer knowledge and user psychology
quotes.text: user research informs your model of your customer and that model informs what you build.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A mental model for treating research as model-building (and decision guidance) rather than a direct feature request pipeline.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: customer knowledge and user psychology
quotes.text: Seeking the solution in a customer interview is never going to work, right? You seek to understand and then you take that away and you can think through what the model should look like and how things should change as a result.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Actionable interviewing advice: focus on understanding problems and context, then synthesize solutions afterward via a customer model.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: growth strategy and influence skills
quotes.text: But in growth strategy, there's three. The first one is growth loop modeling. So really understanding how you grow and where you should be spending your time. What acquires users? What retains them? What monetizes them?
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A crisp framework for diagnosing growth by mapping loops across acquisition, retention, and monetization to guide focus.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: growth strategy and influence skills
quotes.text: The second one is capital allocation and forecasting. This is basically where are you deploying either your money, your people, how are you managing the portfolio and how are you projecting that out into the future? And that's a really hard one. You have to become best buddies with your finance friends in order to do that.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Actionable advice that growth strategy requires portfolio thinking and tight partnership with finance, not just experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: growth strategy and influence skills
quotes.text: So you have to be able to sequence the work much like in building a product, right? Building your growth strategy, you have to sequence it. That sequence has to make sense based on your growth models. You have to have the capital or the people to allocate to that stuff. And you have to be able to build a series of hypotheses in a series of solutions to test against those hypotheses so that you can learn and then productize to those learnings.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A methodology for turning growth into an executable roadmap: sequencing, resourcing, hypothesis testing, and productizing learnings.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: growth strategy and influence skills
quotes.text: And this is hard in growth because often growth can be viewed as at odds with really thoughtful and quality craftsmanship and product building, but it's not. Those things go hand in hand.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that positions growth and product craft as complementary rather than competing priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: growth strategy and influence skills
quotes.text: And I would say, this is the pinnacle, right? This is the hardest one. It's a lifelong journey. It relies very extensively on understanding people and who you're talking to. And those people can be very different from company to company and the currency that they trade in can be really different.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of influence as the highest-leverage growth skill, requiring continual adaptation to stakeholder incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring up-and-coming growth talent: what to prioritize
quotes.text: So if you're going to hire a junior person, the key is, how do you help them learn? And I think if you don't know what you're doing as the founder or the leader, it's hard. You're not going to be able to help them yourself. So you've got to be willing to invest in advisors like me, outside education, mentorship, coaching, otherwise, what's going to happen is that very driven, hungry and enthusiastic person is going to run through a lot of brick walls, which is great, except they're going to miss the fact that the door was standing right next to the wall that they just ran through and you're going to end up with a lot of bricks on the ground.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A practical warning that junior growth hires need structured mentorship/advisors or they’ll waste effort despite high motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring up-and-coming growth talent: what to prioritize
quotes.text: And those are the two most important competencies when you're bringing in a younger, earlier stage person because teaching somebody how to execute is not that fun, right? That's a hard skill.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A hiring heuristic: prioritize execution ability (and customer knowledge) because execution is difficult to teach after the fact.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring up-and-coming growth talent: what to prioritize
quotes.text: The ability to execute is something like executive function skills and things like that. If you haven't developed those by the time you are an adult, I don't know that I'm going to be able to teach you and I'm certainly probably not the right person to teach you.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that “execution” is closer to foundational personal capability than a trainable on-the-job skill.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring up-and-coming growth talent: what to prioritize
quotes.text: And I'm like, "Wow, this is a guy that really knows how to get stuff done and is so much so that he's pausing his interview process so that he could go get a thing done for his company that he's actively trying to leave, but he's got this work ethic and this execution."
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A concrete interview story illustrating how to spot real execution/work ethic signals in candidates.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring up-and-coming growth talent: what to prioritize
quotes.text: I tend to skew more towards internal hire to be perfectly honest, because I believe in creating opportunity inside a company
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A clear preference that challenges the default “go external for growth” instinct and points to internal mobility as a strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Internal transfers vs specialists (SEO/paid growth)
quotes.text: I would bucket that type of person into a specialist.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Clarifies that SEO/paid growth roles should be treated differently from generalist growth hires by explicitly categorizing them as specialists.

quotes.topic_title: Internal transfers vs specialists (SEO/paid growth)
quotes.text: And one of the archetypes that I talk about is this idea of the painter versus the architect versus the surgeon.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable hiring framework (painter/architect/surgeon) practitioners can use to match roles to the type of work needed.

quotes.topic_title: Internal transfers vs specialists (SEO/paid growth)
quotes.text: I don't actually recommend hiring that as your first hire, but when you are onto something and you really need expertise and you don't have that expertise internally, yes, I think hiring externally is the right thing to do at that point because those are really specific skills that some people have taken years to learn.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Gives actionable sequencing advice: delay specialist hires until there’s traction and a clear expertise gap, then hire externally.

quotes.topic_title: Internal transfers vs specialists (SEO/paid growth)
quotes.text: And I can't just teach someone SEO over the course of a weekend and expect that they're really going to get it.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Counters the “any smart generalist can learn it quickly” assumption by emphasizing the depth and time required for channel mastery.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Eppo experimentation platform
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical tooling gap that can slow down experimentation programs and force teams into inefficient workarounds.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Eppo experimentation platform
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools, or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about hidden costs and common failure modes when experimentation infrastructure doesn’t fit the growth stack.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Eppo experimentation platform
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of an analysis methodology (segmented slicing) that helps teams find meaningful differences and root causes faster.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Eppo experimentation platform
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more, delivering results quickly, avoiding annoying prolonged analytic cycles and helping you easily get to the root cause of any issue you discover.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes speed-to-insight and root-cause analysis as key levers for improving experimentation throughput and decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Eppo experimentation platform
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic clickthrough metrics and instead, you turn north star metrics like activation, retention, subscriptions and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable guidance to optimize experiments around north-star outcomes rather than shallow proxy metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as an underappreciated growth lever
quotes.text: The first thing I would say is, onboarding is the only part of your product experience that a hundred percent of people are ever going to touch. Good luck getting a hundred percent feature adoption of anything else in your product right? But onboarding is the thing that you have to go through in order to use the product.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A clear prioritization framework: onboarding is uniquely universal, making it a high-leverage place to invest versus any single feature.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as an underappreciated growth lever
quotes.text: So I like to think of your brand is the promise that you're making and your product experience is your delivery of that promise. And those two things have to be in lockstep with each other or you're going to have mismatched expectations and some really disappointed customers.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for aligning marketing/positioning with onboarding so expectations match reality.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as an underappreciated growth lever
quotes.text: I have seen companies shift their curve outward by 10, 15, 20 percentage points from making those changes, especially when you consider that churn is most likely to happen in the very earliest usage of the product. If you can get people past that hump, it's a really invaluable part of the product to work on.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Quantifies the retention upside and focuses attention on the early “churn hump” where onboarding improvements matter most.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as an underappreciated growth lever
quotes.text: What we realized through a lot of experimentation was the idea of connecting someone with a human being the right person at the right time would improve the first month of revenue or the second month of revenue that a creator made on the platform by 25%.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A concrete example of “product-led sales” during onboarding producing a large, measurable revenue lift.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as an underappreciated growth lever
quotes.text: And then the productization of that, the best things to do turned out to be things like one of our product principles, which became opinionated defaults, which is basically making it hard to do the wrong thing when you're setting up your Patreon page and easy to do the right thing but not eliminating choice.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: turn human onboarding learnings into scalable “opinionated defaults” and guardrails.

quotes.topic_title: Opinionated defaults and conversion vs retention tradeoffs
quotes.text: I actually think if you're doing it right, sometimes conversion should actually decrease a little bit.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Contrarian reminder that optimizing onboarding for long-term outcomes can mean accepting lower top-of-funnel completion.

quotes.topic_title: Opinionated defaults and conversion vs retention tradeoffs
quotes.text: So you might actually have fewer people getting all the way through successfully, but I think that's okay because a lot of those people were probably not the right people for your product, which means they wouldn't have been engaged customers, they probably would have churned.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Frames onboarding as a qualification filter that improves retention by preventing poor-fit users from converting.

quotes.topic_title: Opinionated defaults and conversion vs retention tradeoffs
quotes.text: So when you're experimenting, you have to look at these push and pull metrics of these opposing metrics.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: Actionable experimentation guidance: evaluate onboarding changes with paired conversion/retention metrics rather than a single KPI.

quotes.topic_title: Opinionated defaults and conversion vs retention tradeoffs
quotes.text: But overall, I find that the biggest impact that you'll have is on retaining users because you are trying to connect them to the value that your product offers and form a habit.
quotes.speaker: Adam Fishman
quotes.context: A practical mental model for onboarding: accelerate time-to-value and habit formation to drive retention.

quotes.topic_title: Opinionated defaults and conversion vs retention tradeoffs
quotes.text: And so what we got to eventually, is we tried to figure out, are you a professional host that knows what you're doing? Are you a mom and pop that's just trying this out? And then based on that, either block your entire calendar, keep it all open, or somewhere in between.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of “smart/opinionated defaults” by segmenting users and setting guardrails that prevent early mistakes.
